revision.text:
{{COI|date=December 2015}} {{Undue weight|to=his controversial political viewpoints when his primary area of notability is stand-up comedy|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Ivor Dembina | image = Ivordembina2.jpg | image_size = 220 | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Ivor Joseph Dembina | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1951|4|14|df=y}} | birth_place = [[London]], [[England]] | death_date = | death_place = | medium = [[Stand-up comedy|Stand up]], [[Writer]], [[Comedy club]] curator | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] | active = 1987–present | genre = [[Alternative comedy]] | subject = [[Jewish culture]], [[Current events]], [[Sex]], [[Human interaction]], [[Racism]] | influences = | influenced = | spouse = {{marriage|Joan Mary Badcock |1979|1980|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Judith Hilda Dimant|1994|1996|reason=divorced}} | children = Anja Mary, Luis George | domesticpartner = | notable_work = | signature = | website = {{URL|http://www.thinkbeforeyoulaugh.com/}} | footnotes = | module = }} '''Ivor Joseph Dembina''' (born 14 April 1951) is a British stand-up comedian and writer in the alternative tradition from London.{{cite web|title=Ivor Dembina review|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2010/mar/25/ivor-dembina-review|website=The Guardian Newspaper}} ==Career== Dembina attributed his early "reputation for generally doing some decent gigs" to having "the brains to make sure there is a microphone facing the right way." In 1987, together with club promoter, [[Addison Cresswell]], he founded the Comedy Boom venue at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in the basement of the Abercraig Lounge. It was the Edinburgh Festival Fringe's first venue that exclusively hosted stand-up comedy, and ran for five years. After that, his career veered towards performance. He created and compèred a show called Comic Abuse at [[Pleasance Courtyard]] in the late 80s, which became a successful fixture and introduced acts such as [[Jo Brand]] and [[Jack Dee]]. Dembina runs the Hampstead Comedy Club in North London, which he founded in 1994.{{cite web|title=Comedian Ivor Dembina on how money and TV altered British alternative comedy.|url=http://thejohnfleming.wordpress.com/2014/03/10/comedian-ivor-dembina-on-how-money-tv-altered-british-alternative-comedy/|website=John Fleming's Blog}} He is cited as an early influence by [[Stewart Lee]].{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Stewart|title=How I escaped my certain fate : the life and deaths of a stand-up comedian|date=2010|publisher=Faber and Faber|location=London|isbn=978-0-571-25480-4}} He wrote for the first season of the [[Omid Djalili]] Show on BBC1.{{cite web|title=The Omid Djalili Show Cast and Crew|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/the_omid_djalili_show/details/|website=British Comedy Guide|accessdate=31 August 2014}} He appeared in the first season of Eye Spy as 'Jewish Dad' on [[Channel 4]].{{cite web|title=Eye Spy Cast and Crew|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3002664/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|website=Internet Movie Database (IMDb)}} He was the first stand-up comedian to perform a solo comedy show at the UK [[Houses of Parliament]].{{cite web|title=Ivor Dembina Parliament Stand-Up|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2010/mar/16/ivor-dembina-parliament-standup|website=The Guardian Newspaper}}{{cite web|title=Observations: A comic Strip in Westminster|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/comedy/features/observations-a-comic-strip-in-westminster-1923465.html|website=The Independent Newspaper|accessdate=31 August 2014}} Dembina's comedy focuses on his [[Jewish]] background and his political outlook.{{cite web|title=Old Jewish Jokes 2014 review| url=http://www.wow247.co.uk/blog/2014/08/20/old-jewish-jokes/|website=The Scotsman Newspaper}} He toured his show about the Israel-Palestine conflict, 'This is Not a Subject For Comedy', in [[Israel]] and on the West Bank.{{cite web|title=A perfect Subject for Comedy| url=http://www.hanitzotz.com/culture/Dembina.htm|website=Hanitzotz Publishing House}} In 1998 he wrote and performed a show entitled SadoJudaism in which he talked about the worlds of [[fetishism]] and [[prostitution]] through Jewish eyes.{{cite web|title=Beats me what they see in sado- masochism| url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/beats-me-what-they-see-in-sado-masochism-1-861658|website=The Scotsman Newspaper}} Stewart Lee credits him for correcting his microphone technique during a new act competition in 1990, calling him "the [[Obi-Wan Kenobi]] of comedy". ==Social activism== Dembina has attracted attention for his outspoken anti-Zionist and socialist views. In 2004, while on his way to perform stand-up comedy in Israel and the West Bank, Ivor was detained for several hours by Israeli police at [[Ben Gurion Airport]] after his name reportedly turned up on a list of "known radicals".{{cite web|title=Comic detained in Israel|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2004/10/13/995/comic_detained_in_Israel|website=Chortle}} In 2008, Dembina organised a comedy event called "60 Years: What A State" on Israel's independence day, [[Yom Ha'atzmaut]]. Featuring [[Jeremy Hardy]], [[Mark Steel]], [[Reginald D Hunter]] and [[Shazia Mirza]], it was on the same evening a gala event organised by the [[Zionist Federation of Great Britain and Ireland|Zionist Federation]] at the Wembley Arena celebrated 60 years of the Israeli state. Ivor branded the gala's headliner, American comedian [[Jackie Mason]], a "bad Jewish joke", citing Mason's support for Israel and the fact that comedian [[Ray Hanania]], of Palestinian descent, had been dropped from supporting Mason on tour in 2002. Ivor said: "Never mind Israel not wanting to share Jerusalem with Palestinians, he won't even share a stage with one."{{cite web|title=Mason rapped for Zionist gigl|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2008/04/28/6697/mason_rapped_for_Zionist_gig|website=Chortle}} In 2011, Dembina threatened legal action and called for an investigation after a protester interrupted his Edinburgh Fringe preview show at a Jewish community centre in Golders Green, accusing him of performing a "tame version for a Jewish audience" and demanding that he reveal his anti-Israel views. Other activists picketed outside and handed out flyers.{{cite web|title=Demonstrators picket comic’s Ivy House performance|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/51991/ivor-dembinas-show-no-joke-protester|website=Jewish Chronicle Newspaper}} Ivor said afterwards: "In 25 years in Jewish comedy, during which I have performed both in Britain and abroad—including in Israel—this is the first time someone has attended a performance of mine with the apparent intention of sabotaging it." In late 2013 and early 2014, Dembina joined other artists and writers including [[Nigel Kennedy]], [[Yasmin Alibhai-Brown]] and [[Mark Steel]] at St James's Church, Piccadilly for Bethlehem Unwrapped, a festival during the Christmas season that drew attention to the [[Israeli West Bank barrier]].{{cite web|title=Bethlehem Unwrapped|url=http://www.palestinecampaign.org/events/bethlehem-unwrapped/|website=PSC}} In 2014, Dembina caused consternation among sections of the Jewish community for organising a benefit show for the people of the [[Gaza Strip]] with [[Daniel Kitson]], [[Josie Long]] and fellow Jewish comic [[Andy Zaltzman]].{{cite web|title=FREE GAZA!|url=http://www.gildedballoon.co.uk/tickets/performances.php?eventId=14:599|website=Gilded Balloon Edinburgh Fringe Website}} Also in 2014, he angered some other Jewish comedians by banning them from his from his club because they publicly endorsed and received payment from an organisation that he claimed was racist, the [[Jewish National Fund]].{{cite web|title=JNF Boycott|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/126655/comedians-fall-out-over-israel-charity-boycott|website=Jewish Chronicle Newspaper}}{{cite web|title=Racist Charity blacklisted|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/comedy/news/jewish-comics-blacklisted-over-support-for-racist-charity-9926891.html|website=The Independent Newspaper}}{{cite web|title=Is the JNF Racist?|url=http://www.jewishnews.co.uk/jnf-racist/|website=The Jewish News}}{{cite web|title=Jewish Community Divided|url=http://www.beyondthejoke.co.uk/content/1297/news-jewish-comedy-community-divided-over-xmas-gig|website=Beyond the Joke blog}}{{cite web|title=The JNF Hit Back|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/126839/jnf-hits-back-comedian-who-called-it-racist|website=Jewish Chronicle Newspaper}} In February 2015, he joined 700 other UK artists including [[Brian Eno]], [[Mike Leigh]] and [[Liz Lochhead]] as a signatory to a [[boycotts of Israel|cultural boycott of Israel]].{{cite web|title=Cultural Boycott of Israel|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/13/cultural-boycott-israel-starts-tomorrow|website=The Guardian Newspaper}}{{cite web|title=Artists For Palestine|url=http://artistsforpalestine.org.uk/pledge-signatories/}} In 2015, Dembina also attracted the interest of the political community for his willingness to use sensitive subjects such as the Holocaust, Israel and Jewish stereotypes in his material.{{cite web|title=Jewish Jokes Not Antisemetic|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/jewish-jokes-are-not-antisemitic-if-told-in-good-faith-10050108.html|website=The Independent Newspaper}} Dembina is a [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] member of the [[Vauxhall (UK Parliament constituency)|Vauxhall]] [[Constituency Labour Party]].{{cite web |url=http://www.jewishvoiceforlabour.org.uk/jvl/a-jvl-statement-on-the-current-attacks-on-jeremy-corbyn/|title=A statement from Jewish Labour members on the current attacks on Jeremy Corbyn|publisher=Jewish Voice for Labour|date=26 March 2018|accessdate=1 June 2018}} In April 2016, he was one of 82 Jewish members and supporters of the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and of [[Jeremy Corbyn]]'s [[Labour Party leadership of Jeremy Corbyn|leadership]] who wrote an open letter to ''[[The Guardian]]'' stating that they "do not accept that antisemitism is 'rife' in the Labour party" and that "these accusations are part of a wider campaign against the Labour leadership, and they have been timed particularly to do damage to the Labour party and its prospects in [[United Kingdom local elections, 2016|elections in the coming week]]."{{cite news |last= |first= |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/apr/29/labour-antisemitism-and-where-jeremy-corbyn-goes-from-here|title=Labour, antisemitism and where Jeremy Corbyn goes from here|work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=29 April 2016|accessdate=1 June 2018}} ==Notable performances and tours== ===The Cochrane Theatre=== In 1994 Ivor hosted a benefit for ''Jewish Socialist'' magazine at the Cochrane Theatre with [[Jo Brand]], [[Jeremy Hardy]], [[Linda Smith (comedian)|Linda Smith]] and [[Arnold Brown (comedian)|Arnold Brown]] {{cite web|title=Jewish Socialist Group| url=http://www.jewishsocialist.org.uk/about/history|website=Jewish Socialist Group}} ===Middle East=== Ivor toured Israel and the West Bank with his show ''This is Not a Subject for Comedy'' in 2003. ===UK Houses of Parliament=== Ivor performed the first ever comedy gig at the UK Houses of Parliament in 2010. ===Edinburgh shows=== Ivor has performed at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] since 1991.{{cite web|title=Comedian Ivor Dembina| url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/i/462/ivor_dembina|website=Chortle Comedy Website|accessdate=31 August 2014}}{{cite web|title=Ivor Dembina shows|url=http://special.lib.gla.ac.uk/sta/search/detaile.cfm?EID=20456|website=University of Glasgow Scottish Theatre Archive}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Show Title !Co-performer/Guests !Year !Venue |- | Comic Abuse | Compere Ivor Dembina with [[Jack Dee]], [[Jo Brand]], [[Mark Thomas]], Phil Cornwall, Felix Dexter, Dave Cohen, James Macabre, Patrick Marber and Jim Tavare | 1988–1993 | [[The Pleasance]] |- | Stand Up Jewish Comedy | solo show | 1994 | [[The Pleasance]] |- | Arab and the Jew | [[Omid Djalili]] | 1998 | [[The Pleasance]] |- | Ivor Dembina: Jewish Comedy – Free at Last | solo show | 2007 | Linsay's Basement |- | This is Not a Subject for Comedy | solo show | 2008 | Espionage |- | Laughing Horse Free Comedy Selection | Compere Ivor Dembina with a mixed bill | 2008 | Espionage |- | Free Jewish Comedy | solo show | 2011 | The Counting House |- | Ivor's Other Show | solo show | 2011 | The Counting House |- | Old Jewish Jokes | solo show | 2012 | Bar 50 |- | Old Jewish Jokes | solo show | 2013 | Bar 50 |- | Zapp & Dembina – Comedy After Lunch | Andy Zapp and guests | 2013 | Cowgatehead |- | Free Gaza! | [[Daniel Kitson]], [[Josie Long]] and [[Andy Zaltzman]] | 2014 | [[The Gilded Balloon]] |- | Old Jewish Jokes | solo show | 2014 | [[The Gilded Balloon]] |- | Zapp & Dembina | Andy Zapp and guests | 2014 | Cowgatehead |- | New Jewish Jokes | solo show | 2015 | [[The Stand Comedy Club]] |} ==Written Works== Ivor has contributed to many comedy books and been featured in several others. ===Contributor=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Title !Editor !Released !Publisher !Notes |- | ''Because I Tell a Joke or Two: Comedy, Politics and Social Difference'' | Stephen Wagg | 2004 | Routledge | {{ISBN|978-1134794331}} |- | ''Getting the Joke: The Art of Stand-up Comedy'' | Oliver Double | 2005 | A&C Black | {{ISBN|978-0413774767}} |- | ''Funny You Should Say That: A Compendium of Jokes, Quips and Quotations from Cicero to the Simpsons'' | Andrew Martin | 2006 | Penguin | {{ISBN|978-0140515091}} |- | ''Dim Wit: The Funniest, Stupidest Things Ever Said'' | Rosemarie Jarski | 2008 | Random House | {{ISBN|978-1407024684}} |- | ''How to Be Averagely Successful at Comedy'' | Dave Cohen | 2013 | Acorn Independent Press | {{ISBN|978-1909121614}} |- | ''Performing Live Comedy'' | Chris Ritchie | 2013 | A&C Black | {{ISBN|978-1408146439}} |- | ''Words from the Wise: Over 6,000 of the Smartest Things Ever Said'' | Rosemarie Jarski | 2013 | Skyhorse Publishing, Inc | {{ISBN|978-1628732733}} |} ==Comedy Clubs== Since 1985, Ivor has founded and run several comedy clubs. The Hampstead Comedy Club is the only one still operating.{{when|date=July 2016}} * Founded the Red Rose Comedy Club in Finsbury Park, London in 1985. {{cite web | title = Red Rose Club | publisher=Seven Sisters Stories | url = http://www.sevensistersstories.com/gallery/red-rose-club | accessdate = 2014-11-26 }} * * Founded the Comedy Boom with club promoter, [[Addison Cresswell]] in Edinburgh in 1987. The Edinburgh Festival Fringe's first venue for Stand-Up Comedy.{{cite web|title=How To Promote a Fringe Show|url=http://theianfox.wordpress.com/2010/10/04/how-to-promote-a-free-festival-show/|website=How To Promote a Fringe Show}} * * Founded the Hampstead Comedy Club in 1994. It was originally held at the Washington Arms in Belsize Park, London. It currently resides at the Camden Head in Camden Town, London.{{cite web|title=Hampstead Comedy Club|url=http://www.hampsteadcomedy.co.uk/?page_id=8|website=Hamptead Comedy Club}} * * Founded the Brixton Comedy Club in the Hobgoblin, Brixton, London in 1999.{{cite web|title=Brixton Comedy Club|url=http://www.brixtoncomedy.co.uk/|website=Brixton Comedy Club}} ==Critical opinion== ''The Skinny'' magazine commented that there is something "modest and eternal" about him. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |title=How Comedy Captured the Edinburgh Fringe: Part 3 |last=Venables |first=Ben |publisher=[[The Skinny (magazine)|The Skinny]] |url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/comedy/opinion/how-comedy-captured-the-edinburgh-fringe-part-3 |date=6 June 2017 |access-date=13 October 2017}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dembina, Ivor}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English Jews]] [[Category:English male comedians]] [[Category:English stand-up comedians]] [[Category:English comedy writers]] [[Category:English socialists]] [[Category:Jewish male comedians]] [[Category:Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] [[Category:Labour Party (UK) people]]
